review_title: This place has problems, but depending who you work with it may be worth it
pros: You might get to work with some really great, talented, people.  Flexible hours, good work/life balance.  Good pay rates given that Windsor is an inexpensive city to live in by Canadian standards.
cons:
Dysfunctional.  Too many professors are awful at their jobs, and nothing is done about it because they have tenure: proving just cause for termination is too time consuming and difficult to do.

The good professors are totally overburdened, and do not have enough time to do their jobs correctly.

review_title: Working and meeting new people was the best experienced that can be gained from the work study position.
job_title: Work Study Student in Windsor, ON
pros: Advantages of working here is the flexible schedule for school and work. They understand that a student who is working part-time within the school has education commitments, extra -curricular commitments and family commitments. They also have a great group of co-workers to work with and socialize on our free time.
cons: Some downsides of working here is the work that it is repetitive and is tedious at times. The work load assigned is not consistent, where some work is passed onto you when the superior doesn't want to do it.

pros: Decent wages, good benefits,  friendly Co workers, grounds are acceptable, beautiful Alumni Field. Best woman's basketball team in the nation
cons: President of the university is corrupt. Should fire recruiting staff. Forcing students to travel to the downtown core for classes and quoted saying "it's  the students problem"  when asked how are the students to get downtown. Lay offs and out sourcing when the higher ups get raises.

pros: Great place to get you education and to get relevant experience. You need to join a lab or a research team in order to get full experience, otherwise you may not get practical experience that you need.
cons: lab work is not that difficult and demanding, I was fortunate enough to join the lab and to get all my experience through that. however, have I relied solely on the lab work it would not be enough

pros: Good place to expand your network in Windsor and try teaching if you haven't done so in the past - easier to get a sessional teaching position here than other universities in Ontario.
cons:
- Disorganized management and administration - they don't answer questions on a timely basis and don't help in setting up your course so you're scrambling at the last minute so students aren't impacted.
- Instead of providing a comprehensive welcome package when you start, they provide you with forms that are not the most current and you have to contact different departments to get your access set-up. For example, payroll forms are not provided along with your offer letter and rather you have to call someone and get them to email you and then return them back to that specific person instead of filling out all forms and returning to one person to take care of. When you are a part-time sessional professor and have a separate full-time job this makes the whole process very difficult.
- Basic questions on logistics of how classes work for a first-time teaching position aren't provided, people pass off the buck to other people and you have to email numerous people to get an answer. Secretaries are generally useless and lazy. When you email them they frequently tell you "they're too busy".
- The school has certain academic policies in place that students are to follow, such as rescheduling exams, which are not followed. Students frequently send emails saying they're on vacation when the exam is scheduled and expect you to reschedule them. When you say no, they approach the administration and administration will then tell you to give them another chance (or they automatically fill out the change forms for you and expect you to sign off on them). This contributes to the poor reputation of the university. 
- Administration caters to whatever students want. While this generally maintains good student relations, this provides for an environment where academic standards are sub-par and students are given high grades that they do not deserve. It's no wonder that graduates can't find jobs in the real world and a University of Windsor degree doesn't hold much value.
- If you interested in academics, it's a good institution to get your foot in the door for other opportunities. I can't imagine working here full-time and being proud to be a professor at this institution.
- Pay for sessional staff is approximately $6,800 per course for a 3 month course (12 weeks). While this sounds great, when you think about the after-tax money you're going to receive, it's not worth the amount of hours you're required to put in to make up for the incompetence of administration while teach effectively. Also, you are not provided with any teaching materials other than the textbook and its resources and are required to create the entire course. 
- Prior to teaching here, I'd frequently heard this institution being referred to as "Last Chance U". Now I understand why that moniker is used.

pros: The CEO of the University was really warm and friendly to us. We had a meeting, and it felt like equals. The University of Windsor is also great for references, the professors and hiring managers will try to get you a great job and help you.
cons: They are administratively unorganized. I did not get my first pay-check till 2 months later. Quite disappointing since I brought it up to my Boss a few times. It's evident they are not strict on following regulations.

pros: Wages are competitive and benefits are good
cons: Enrollment is dropping, the quality of student experience has dropped significantly in the last ten years.  Management doesn't seem to care and don't seem to be able to make a connection between the quality of education provided and enrollment.

pros: Working with co workers I get along with mostly everyone and I have never been  unhappy with who I was working with
cons: not being able to work full time..... this would be a great place to work full time given the opportunity.  I would love that.

job_title: Research Assistant In Statistics Department in Windsor, ON
pros: Learned a lot about optimization, team worked well together, weekly meetings were efficient. Professor and students were very patient with me even though I was only in high school at the time. They respected and considered my input when there were challenges.
cons: This is probably only pertinent to high school students, but sometimes it could be intimidating since all the students have had a lot more training in terms of relevant courses, etc. However, they also trusted me with my part of the research.

pros: a lot to learn and plenty of space to grow, good for job hunting after graduation if you dont have any work experience.
cons: i have not found any yet. maybe it depends on individuals. and RAs do not have the same salary. it varies from person to person.

job_title: Research Associate & Project/Lab Manager in Windsor, ON
pros: I really enjoyed being a Post Doctoral Fellow for the Loeb Research Group.  My supervisor was not just a boss but a great mentor and friend. The research was exciting and the pay was decent. The benefits were a great package.
cons: The pay isn't great and you have to put in a fair amount of hours at times to keep projects moving. So you often work late during the week and come in on the weekends.

pros: Great faculty members and usually is assigned a reasonable workload.  Job tasks are varied and graduate assistants can interact with undergraduate students in many different roles.
cons: Students can be difficult to deal with at times and the task of marking assignments and exams can become tedious.
